Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Hydrogen Chemistry of Earth Abundant Metals
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award in the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) program in the Division of Chemistry supports a project by Professor Michael Heinekey in the Department of Chemistry at the University of Washington. The project will explore the chemistry of hydrogen. Hydrogen has the potential to become a significant transportation fuel and an important part of our energy infrastructure. Progress in this area has been hindered by the cost and limited supply of platinum and related metals, which are the current materials of choice for catalysis of hydrogen production and utilization. This project will explore the use of less expensive and more abundant metals such as iron, nickel and cobalt. This project will also provide excellent interdisciplinary training of undergraduate and graduate students, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences. It will allow both Professor Heinekey and students to continue to participate in outreach activities directed to the general public.

Biomimetic approaches to hydrogen activation will be explored, with inspiration provided by the recently discovered active site structures of hydrogenase enzymes. Model complexes will be prepared with one iron center, two iron centers and iron/nickel pairs, along with appropriate co-ligands, including carbon monoxide and isonitrile ligands. The binding of hydrogen to these complexes will be studied as a model for the oxidized form of the enzyme.Additional studies of hydrogen binding to iron and nickel complexes will be undertaken to elucidate the mechanism of proton transfer from bound hydrogen to various bases. Interconversion of dihydrogen, terminal hydride and bridging hydride ligands will also be investigated as a model for the activation of hydrogen by the hydrogenase enzymes. Hydrogen complexes will also be studied as catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of carbon chlorine bonds in Freons, which may lead to practical processes for recycling of these ozone depleting molecules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In our Universe, Hydrogen is the most abundant of the chemical elements.  On Earth, it is commonly found in the form of liquid water (H2O). Hydrogen in the elemental form (H2) is a gas.  In this form, hydrogen has potential as a fuel and as an energy storage medium. Hydrogen can be converted to electrical energy with high efficiency in a fuel cell. These electrochemical devices require platinum for effective operation.  Platinum is a rare and expensive element, with no significant domestic supply.

This research project has explored the chemical reactions of hydrogen with metals such as iron, cobalt and nickel, which are all inexpensive and abundant. The long term objective of such research is to develop hydrogen utilization chemistry which does not depend upon platinum. In part, this research is inspired by biology.  Several anaerobic (living without oxygen) micro-organisms have been found to use and enzyme known as hydrogenase to utilize hydrogen.  The metals involved are iron and nickel (not platinum!). Part of the reserarch project has involved the preparation of metal containing complexes which react with hydrogen to form new molecules known as "hydrogen complexes".  An example of this is the cobalt complex shown below:

At the time that we reported this complex, it was the first cobalt complex of hydrogen to be prepared. This complex has limited stability and must be prepared and observed below room temperature.  We have made considerable efforts to improve the stability of these cobalt complexes by varying the supporting ligands, but all complexes prepared to date are similarly unstable. With nickel, we have prepared a similar complex which is quite stable at room temperature. 

Work with iron complexes has been directed to the preparation and reactivity of dinuclear iron complexes (containing two iron atoms) which resemble the active site of the iron hydrogenase enzyme.  One such complex has been shown to react directly with hydrogen gas under mild conditions.

While not direclty relevant to the chemistry outlined above, we have continued to explore iridium chemistry using new complexes which exhibit enhanced reactivity with hydrogen gas.

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2018
Modified by: D. Michael Heinekey
